content.headline: Comprehensive Guide to Fetal Development from Conception to Birth
content.intro: Fetal development is an orderly and intricate process that begins before you even know you're pregnant and ends with the birth of your baby. There are three main stages of fetal development: germinal, embryonic and fetal.

sections.title: The Three Stages of Fetal Development
sections.content: Understanding the progression from conception to birth:
points: Germinal Stage: Shortest stage beginning at conception, zygote divides and becomes blastocyst
Embryonic Stage: Weeks 3-8, embryo develops distinct human characteristics and major organs
Fetal Stage: Week 9 to birth, fetus grows and matures all body systems and features

sections.title: First Trimester Development (Weeks 1-12)
sections.content: The most critical period for organ formation:
points: Week 5: Neural tube forms, tiny heart begins pulsing
Week 6: Arm and leg buds develop, blood circulation begins
Week 8: All major organs and body systems developing
Week 12: Most critical development complete, risk of miscarriage decreases

sections.title: Second Trimester Development (Weeks 13-26)
sections.content: Rapid growth and the beginning of movement:
points: Week 16: Can hear sounds, fingerprints begin forming
Week 20: You may feel baby's first movements (quickening)
Week 24: Lungs developing, skin still translucent
Baby practices breathing and develops sleep-wake cycles

sections.title: Third Trimester Development (Weeks 27-40)
points: Week 28: Eyes can open and blink, lungs producing surfactant
Week 32: Most organs well-formed except lungs and brain
Week 37: Considered full-term, baby gains 0.5 pounds weekly
Week 40: Ready for birth, average 7-9 pounds

sections.title: Key Developmental Milestones
sections.content: Important markers in your baby's growth journey:
points: Most critical development occurs in first 13 weeks
Baby's sex determined around week 9
Rapid brain development in third trimester
Vernix and lanugo protect skin in womb
Bones harden but skull remains soft for birth

content.headline: Understanding Medication Research and Safety During Pregnancy
content.intro: Pregnant and lactating women have historically been excluded from clinical drug research, leading to most medications being used 'off-label' during pregnancy. Recent changes aim to improve safety data for medications used during pregnancy and lactation.

sections.title: The Challenge of Medication Use in Pregnancy
sections.content: Current landscape of medication safety during pregnancy:
points: 40-60% of pregnant women take 1 or more prescription medications
Over 90% of medications lack appropriate labeling for pregnancy use
Most medications are used 'off-label' during pregnancy
Pregnant women were historically excluded from clinical trials

sections.title: Historical Context and Changes
sections.content: Evolution of medication safety research in pregnancy:
points: 1977 FDA guidelines prevented pregnant women from clinical trials
1993 NIH Revitalization Act required inclusion of women in research
Recent removal of 'vulnerable' classification for pregnant women
Increased focus on preexisting conditions in pregnancy

sections.title: Current Research Initiatives
sections.content: Efforts to improve medication safety data:
points: Obstetric-Fetal Pharmacology Research Centers established
Studying pharmacokinetics of common pregnancy medications
Research on diabetes, hypertension, and infection treatments
Focus on individualized dosing during pregnancy

sections.title: Important Considerations
sections.content: What every pregnant woman should know about medications:
points: Always consult your provider before taking any medication
Discuss preexisting conditions and necessary medications early
Understand that medication needs may change during pregnancy
Ask about latest research on specific medications you need
